title: REVIEW: Don't Get Your Vicars in a Twist, Salisbury Studio Theatre
text:
0 comments 
HARD-UP Churchwarden George has let the empty vicarage to a travelling theatre company for a Murder Mystery Weekend to fund his daughter’s wedding, little expecting the ensuing mayhem that results from the new female vicar arriving early, an unexpected visit from the bishop, and half the actors failing to arrive. 
Played at breakneck speed on Colin Hayman’s excellent multi-doored set, the cast, almost all of whom ended up at some point dressed as someone else, never flagged for a moment during the most convoluted of plots involving every misunderstanding and misinterpretation one could possibly imagine, impressively led by the Lee Evans–like Keith Edmund’s hapless Churchwarden and Paul Chalmers’ ‘Luvvie’ thespian Dickie. Share article 
Add some outrageous wigs, falsetto voices, drunken actors, a nymphomaniac, and every conceivable permutation of cross-dressing, and Director Sally Marshall’s impressively well-drilled cast showed that the tradition of the Whitehall Farce is well and truly alive and flourishing.
